properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Collecting History: 125 Years of the National Philatelic Collection at National Postal Museum
properties.description: The National Philatelic Collection celebrates its 125th anniversary in 2011, making it the oldest intact national stamp collection in the world. 'Collecting History' remembers a few of the hundreds of donors who have given their collections to the Smithsonian for the benefit of the nation. It explores the decisive role of twelve successive curators in developing the national collection and exhibiting it to the public. Lastly, it invites you to consider the importance of this national treasure and reflect on what the material within it can teach us about world cultures and the American experience.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Designing Tomorrow: America's World's Fairs of the 1930s at National Building Museum
properties.description: A first-of-its-kind exhibition, 'Designing Tomorrow' will feature nearly 200 never-before-assembled artifacts including building models, architectural remnants, drawings, paintings, prints, furniture, an original RCA TRK-12 television, Elektro the Moto-Man robot, and period film footage.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Great Ape Research Demonstration at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Meet a cognitive researcher and learn about studies being conducted with the Zoo's orangutans and gorillas.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: The Art of Gaman: Arts and Crafts From the Japanese American Internment Camps, 1942-1946 at Renwick Gallery
properties.description: This exhibit will showcase arts and crafts made by Japanese Americans in U.S. internment camps during World War II. On display will be more than 100 objects, many of which are on loan from former internees or their families. The exhibition is based on Delphine Hirasuna's 2005 book 'The Art of Gaman.'

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Gods of Angkor: Bronzes From the National Museum of Cambodia at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: Revealed through 36 exceptional works on display in the Gallery, the fascinating story of bronze sculpture and casting in Cambodia is revealed. Magnificent examples dating from the prehistoric period to the post-Angkorian period (third century BCE to sixteenth century CE) present the origins, uses, and techniques of bronze casting and the development of a distinctly Cambodian style.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Invertebrate House Interpreters at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Explore the complex, fascinating world of invertebrates: corals and crabs, ants and anemones, seashells and spiders. Feeding demonstrations take place every half-hour. Hands-on activities vary daily.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Moon Tears - Lagrimas De Luna at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: 'Moon Tears,' the largest exhibition ever of the Mapuche culture from Chile, features more than 700 exquisite pieces of silver jewelry passed down from grandmother to granddaughter. Beyond beautiful works of art, the jewelry, textiles, and sacred objects in the exhibition record the cosmology, history, and ancestry of the Mapuche that continue to guide their public and medicinal ceremonies.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Kids' Farm Interpreters at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Learn about farming and how taking care of animals takes time, dedication, and knowledge.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Fiona Tan: Rise and Fall at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: This exhibition of photographs and videos by Fiona Tan, born in Indonesia in 1966 and now living in Amsterdam, is the first major presentation of her work in the United States. Tan's installations deftly meld the past with the present in profoundly evocative works that explore the power of images in constructing memories and histories. Whether drawing on old photographs, seventeenth-century Dutch painting, or nineteenth-century orientalist architecture, her conceptual and aesthetic approach adds a compelling dimension to understanding Asian art and culture in the world today.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Great Cats Viewing at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: You are invited to visit with the zoo's lions and tigers.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Tours of the Mary McLeod Bethune Council House at Mary McLeod Bethune Council House
properties.description: Mary McLeod Bethune achieved her greatest national and international recognition at the Washington, DC townhouse at 1318 Vermont Avenue, NW, that is now this Historic Site. It was the first headquarters of the National Council of Negro Women (NCNW) and was her last home in Washington, DC. From here, Bethune and the Council spearheaded strategies and developed programs that advanced the interests of African American women and the Black community.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Havre De Grace and Port Deposit Van Tour at Meadowside Nature Center
properties.description: Explore the history of these two small historic towns, located on the mouth of the Susquehanna River. We'll take a guided tour of Port Deposit (narrowest town in the US), featuring Tome Memorial United Methodist Church (c. 1872), Paw Paw Museum (c. 1821), and Bainbridge Naval Training Center, where half a million World War II recruits trained. We'll also look for American bald eagles that nest along the Susquehanna and feed off fish below Conowingo Dam. In the afternoon, we'll visit Havre de Grace, including the Concord Point Lighthouse and the Decoy Museum. Snow date 1/27. Naturalist: Sandy Staples.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Winter Waterbird Survey at Jug Bay Wetlands Sanctuary
properties.description: Enjoy the winter beauty of early an winter morning on the Patuxent while counting waterbirds: Canada geese, harriers, eagles, herons, and many different kinds of ducks. Dress for the weather and wear comfortable walking shoes. Bring binoculars & a field guide if you have them, also available to borrow. For adults. No experience necessary. Call 410-741-9330 to register.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Primate Interpreters at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Learn about some of our closest relatives, great and lesser apes - gorillas, orangutans and gibbons - and discuss the idea of animal thinking.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: LEGO Architecture: Towering Ambition at National Building Museum
properties.description: This exhibit features 15 LEGO models built by LEGO certified professional Adam Reed Tucker. The buildings and structures that Tucker has assembled are some of the most recognizable works of architecture in the world, including: the Empire State Building, the World Trade Center, Trump Tower, the St. Louis Arch, and the Burj Khalfia.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Small Mammal House Interpreters at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Learn about a wide variety of mammals, including the three-banded armadillo, naked mole-rat, golden lion tamarin, and banded mongoose.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: The Body Inside and Out: Anatomical Literature and Art Theory Selections From the National Gallery of Art Library at National Gallery of Art - East Building
Jan 13, 2011: Perspectives: Hai Bo at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: Trained as a painter, Hai Bo, born in 1962 in Changchun, China, took up photography in the 1980s as he became captivated by the camera's ability to stop time and evoke memories. For over two decades, he has been returning to his hometown in Jilin Province to capture the people and places of his youth, creating deeply moving portraits of resilience amidst the growing isolation of rural China. On display are five stunning, large scale photographs from his Northern Series. These images allow viewers to enter the vast panoramas of the artist's childhood memories, observe the subtle changes of nature across seasons, and encounter the gentle transience of life.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Magna Carta at National Archives
properties.description: This foundation document of English common law was confirmed by Edward I in 1297. Only four originals of the 1297 Magna Carta remain, and only one permanently resides in the United States. Purchased by David M. Rubenstein in 2007, it is on loan to the National Archives.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Bird House Interpreters at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Check out feathers, bones, and eggs and learn about the fascinating world of birds.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Celebrating 100 Years at National Museum of Natural History at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: The Natural History Building first opened its doors to the public on March 17, 1910. The Museum celebrates its 100th birthday with a special exhibition featuring archival and modern photographs highlighting many facets of this building - its people, collections, exhibitions, and outreach throughout the years. Photographs both old and new give snapshots of life and work at the Museum over the past 100 years.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Winter Bird Walk Series at Irvine Nature Center
properties.description: Start your mid-week morning with a pleasant stroll along the trails of a local park. We'll discover which birds are hanging around and talk about their behaviors. Bring binoculars or borrow a pair from us. This program is part of a series (12/16, 2/16), but can be attended individually.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: The Wonder of Light: Touch and Learn at Smithsonian Castle
properties.description: On view in a case are objects from the museums' collections related to light, accompanied by a touch-screen table nearby featuring interactive activities for children that tell stories of light. The name of this exhibition is from the theme of the original Children's Room, "Knowledge begins with Wonder."

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Editors' Picks: the Best of Smithsonian Magazine's 7th Annual Photo Contest at Smithsonian Castle
properties.description: For its 7th annual photo contest, Smithsonian magazine received over 45,000 entries from the United States and around the world in the following five categories: Altered Images, Americana, The Natural World, People, and Travel. A panel of judges selected 50 finalists, 30 of which will be displayed in the Castle.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Victory Mail at National Postal Museum
properties.description: This exhibit showcases the Museum's collection of World War II V-Mail correspondence. V for Victory, a popular symbol of the Second World War, was the inspiration for the name of this new fangled correspondence style.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: The Public Vaults at National Archives
properties.description: 'The Public Vaults' invites visitors into virtual stack areas to discover historic documents, films, maps, and photographs from the National Archives. In interactive displays, visitors may hear Presidents discuss some of the country's greatest challenges, step into the boots of soldiers on the front lines, or follow an investigation of the sinking of the Titanic. Look for a changing display of documents and artifacts from Ronald Reagan's administration in celebration of his 100th birthday.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Chinamania at Freer Gallery of Art
properties.description: Blue-and-white Chinese porcelain became a hot item in London in the 1870s, a craze the British press mockingly dubbed "Chinamania." James McNeill Whistler, an early collector of Chinese porcelain, helped stimulate this fad by depicting such wares in his paintings. The Chinamania exhibition at the Freer explores Chinese porcelain in Whistler's England, where it was first valued as aesthetic inspiration but soon proliferated as a commodity. Featured are twenty-three works of art: blue-and-white porcelain objects from the Peacock Room; eight wash drawings of Kangxi porcelain that Whistler produced for a collector's catalogue; and paintings, pastels, and etchings inspired by the artist's interest in porcelain.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: The Hyperbolic Crochet Coral Reef at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: The hyperbolic crochet coral reef has grown from the discovery that cutting-edge hyperbolic geometry could be found in the intricate structures of coral reefs and represented though the traditional handicraft of crochet. Experience this homage to the disappearing wonder, beauty, and diversity of living reefs that are threatened by pollution and global warming.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: The Charters of Freedom: Our Nation's Founding Documents at National Archives
properties.description: This exhibit takes a fresh look at the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the Bill of Rights.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Taking Shape: Ceramics in Southeast Asia at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: Approximately 200 diverse and visually striking ceramic vessels from Southeast Asia are on display in this exhibit. 'Taking Shape' presents the two basic types of ceramics produced in Southeast Asia - soft, porous earthenware and high-fired stoneware.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Discovering the Civil War, Part Two: Consequences at National Archives
properties.description: This exhibit features the most extensive display ever assembled from the incomparable Civil War holdings of the National Archives. Through unusual perspectives, seldom-seen documents, and engaging interactive exhibits, everyone from novices to Civil War buffs can "discover" the Civil War. This exhibit is on display in the Lawrence F. O'Brien Gallery.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Asia Trail Interpreters at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Learn about giant pandas, sloth bears, clouded leopards, and four other species living on Asia Trail.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Cheetah Conservation Station Interpreters at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Explore the world of the cheetah and other animals at the Cheetah Conservation Station, including Grevy's zebra and scimitar-horned oryx.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Cyprus: Crossroads of Civilizations at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: Located in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, the island of Cyprus has been a crossroads of civilizations for over 11,000 years. Explore the history of Cyprus through a rich collection of antiquities, most of which are traveling outside the country for the first time. Discover the ways in which the human endeavor has shaped and is shaped by the natural environment of this Mediterranean jewel.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Theo Eshetu: Brave New World at Smithsonian National Museum of African Art
properties.description: In this exhibit, Theo Eshetu explores such universal tensions as the relationship between nature and technology and the idea of life as a spectacle. He does so with images that map his personal geography: scenes from a dance performance he filmed at a restaurant in Bali, footage from visits to New York City and Ethiopia, and even a cameo appearance by a box of Kellogg's corn flakes. He collaborated with musician and sound designer Keir Fraser to produce the video's seductive and meditative soundtrack.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Investigating Where We Live at National Building Museum
properties.description: This exhibition presents students' interpretations of D.C. neighborhoods through photography, writing, and original artwork. This year's participants explored Petworth, Trinidad, and the Southwest Waterfront in Washington, D.C.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Postal Inspectors: the Silent Service at National Postal Museum
properties.description: Today about 2,000 postal inspectors are at work across the United States investigating crimes against the mail. By visiting the museum and viewing this exhibit, you'll learn more about the inspectors and what their jobs entail. Sometimes called the silent service, the U.S. Postal Inspection Service is one of the oldest federal law enforcement agencies in the country.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Elephant Viewing at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: The Elephant House will be closed while a new home is built for the elephants. However, they will be on view in their outdoor habitats daily (weather dependent).

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Ice Skating at the Sculpture Garden at National Gallery of Art - Sculpture Garden
properties.description: The National Gallery of Art Sculpture Garden ice-skating rink is open mid-November through mid-March, weather permitting. View magnificent works of sculpture while skating in the open air and enjoying music from the state-of-the-art sound system. Skate rental: $3 (ID required); locker rental: 50 cents ($5 deposit required).

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Negro Leagues Baseball Stamp Art at National Postal Museum
properties.description: This exhibit, on view in the Museum's Franklin Foyer, features original art produced by Kadir Nelson for the creation of the Negro Leagues Baseball stamps, which pay tribute to the all-black professional baseball leagues that operated from 1920 to approximately 1960.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Shaping History Through Service: the Walter Mills Story at Banneker Douglass Museum
properties.description: In 1939, Walter Mills, an educator at Parole Elementary School in Annapolis, MD, fought for African American teachers in Anne Arundel County to receive the same pay rate as white teachers. The court case was successfully argued by attorney and Maryland native Thurgood Marshall and brought an end to unequal pay for teachers in Anne Arundel County, and eventually the entire state of Maryland. This exhibition will include rarely seen photos, objects, and documents in the process of telling the life story of Walter Mills.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: German Drawings From the Walters' Collection at The Walters Art Museum
properties.description: These German drawings from the mid-19th century are notable for their clear storytelling, appealing subject matter and precise draftsmanship. William Walters purchased most of the works in this exhibition during his time in Europe. Highlights include picturesque landscapes, charming animal studies and incisive character sketches.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Supporting the Force: Navy Supply in Action - Ready for Sea, Ready Ashore at United States Navy Memorial and Naval Heritage Center
properties.description: Navy Supply provides the "beans, bullets and black oil" that enable the US Navy to operate around the globe. Navy Supply touches the lives of every sailor with food, laundry, barbers, postal services and ship's stores. On display will be ship models, rare historic artifacts including an 1841 Navy Purser's uniform coat - the oldest known Navy Supply uniform - as well as a World War II WAVE uniform and the uniform and equipment worn by a Navy Advisor in the Vietnam War. In addition, the exhibit will honor the sailors of Navy Supply who've given their lives in the Global War on Terror and those who've received the Nation's top honors. Hands on activities for children include "build a meal" puzzles, interactive cargo handling display model and a "try-on trunk" with flight deck uniforms and equipment used during vertical replenishment operations. A full schedule of events will accompany the exhibit, including food tastings, films, lectures and equipment displays.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: A True North Britain - the Furniture of John Shearer, 1790-1820 at DAR Museum
properties.description: Noted not only for its form but also for the politically charged symbols inlaid in many pieces, the furniture created by John Shearer helps to explore early America's cultural ties to Great Britain during the most contentious period in the two nations' shared history.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: America's Aquatic Treasures at National Aquarium
properties.description: The National Aquarium in Washington, DC, proudly introduces 'America's Aquatic Treasures,' which highlights the animals and habitats preserved and protected by our National Marine Sanctuaries Program.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Guided Tours of the Baltimore Basilica at Baltimore Basilica
properties.description: This tour includes all areas of the church, including the upper church, undercroft, Our Lady Seat of Wisdom Chapel, Crypt, Basilica Museum, and the Pope John Paul II Prayer Garden (upon request). Tours last approximately 45 minutes to one hour. If you would like to incorporate the Pope John Paul II Prayer Garden into your tour, add another 15 minutes.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Tours of the Mary McLeod Bethune Council House at Mary Mc Leod Bethune Council
properties.description: Mary McLeod Bethune achieved her greatest national and international recognition at the Washington, DC townhouse at 1318 Vermont Avenue, NW, that is now this Historic Site. It was the first headquarters of the National Council of Negro Women (NCNW) and was her last home in Washington, DC. From here, Bethune and the Council spearheaded strategies and developed programs that advanced the interests of African American women and the Black community.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Athlete: the Sports Illustrated Photography of Walter Iooss at Newseum
properties.description: On display are more than 40 photos from Iooss's nearly 50-year career, each accompanied by the story behind the image, told in Iooss's own words. The exhibit includes Iooss's most famous photograph, 'The Catch,' which captured the last-minute touchdown catch by San Francisco 49ers' receiver Dwight Clark that ended the Dallas Cowboys' Super Bowl dreams in 1982. Also included are Iooss's personal diaries, filled with collages of his photos, quirky headlines and his handwritten notes. In addition, the exhibit includes an original Newseum-produced video in which Iooss talks about his photos and the bond he forged with his subjects.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Elvis - His Groundbreaking, Hip-Shaking, Newsmaking Story at Newseum
properties.description: Experience the power of Elvis Presley and the explosive impact he had on music and popular culture. The exhibit opens in what would have been Presley's 75th birthday year. It tells the story of Presley as he was portrayed in the news media and explores how his music and physicality pushed the boundaries of mainstream taste and free expression. Produced in collaboration with Elvis Presley Enterprises Inc., the exhibit includes a number of rare objects from the vaults of Graceland that have never been publicly displayed, including private telegrams, letters and documents that chronicle Presley's rise as a music and media sensation. Also on display are rare photographs and original newspapers and magazines covering Presley's career, Presley's iconic 1957 Harley-Davidson motorcycle, the "American Eagle" jumpsuit and cape Presley wore during rehearsals for his 1973 "Aloha From Hawaii" concert and the gold-and-diamond belt presented to Presley in 1969 for breaking Las Vegas attendance records.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: G-Men and Journalists at Newseum
properties.description: This exhibit, featuring approximately 200 artifacts, nearly 300 photographs, dozens of historic newspapers, interactive displays and more, reflects the sometimes cooperative, sometimes combative relationship between the FBI and the news media.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Covering Katrina at Newseum
properties.description: 'Covering Katrina' chronicles the dramatic tale of the media's reporting of the killer storm that struck the Gulf Coast. Never-before-displayed artifacts illustrate the professional challenges and personal losses reporters suffered covering the storm and the sometimes perilous conditions they faced. The exhibit also includes an original Newseum-produced video that features dramatic footage of storm coverage along with vivid and often emotional first-person accounts from newspaper editors and TV journalists who balanced objective reporting with their own personal frustrations.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Amphibians Gallery at National Aquarium
properties.description: Due to their unique biology and the habitats they live in, amphibians are very prone to depletion and mutation from pollution, habitat destruction, urbanization, and environmental change. Many of the amphibians in the United States are listed as endangered, threatened, or in need of protection. These animals, such as the eastern tiger salamander, are beautiful and rarely seen in the wild due to their elusive nature, but are now even harder to find due to dwindling populations. This gallery highlights salamanders, newts, frogs, and toads to display their amazing adaptations and biology.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Visionary Distillations at American Center for Physics
properties.description: 'Visionary Distillations' brings together the photographs of Robert Cassanova, the paintings of Kim Dylla and the sculptures of Minna Newman Nathanson. While their mediums differ, they each seek out the unexpected, and using their imagination, essentialize form to reveal fundamental patterns and connections.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Levi Stephens at The Old Post Office Pavillion Food Court
properties.description: Levi Stephens plays alternative soul.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Elvis at 21: Photographs by Alfred Wertheimer at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: In 1956, Alfred Wertheimer photographed a young and relatively unknown Elvis Presley. Wertheimer's images, taken before record-setting singles, broadcast specials, and hyped Hollywood films, reveal a rock !n' roll legend on the verge of superstardom. 'Elvis at 21: Photographs by Alfred Wertheimer,' a new Smithsonian traveling exhibition, presents 56 of these striking images.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: One Life: Katharine Graham at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: Newspaper publisher Katharine Graham (1917-2001) led an extraordinary life in extraordinary times. Born into privilege, she was catapulted onto the international stage as publisher of The Washington Post during the Watergate scandal. The exhibition includes several photographs to narrate key moments in her life including a portrait by Richard Avedon, drawings, original newspapers from the time of the Watergate scandal, the Pulitzer Prize for her memoir, 'Personal History' (1998) and video of a Living Self-Portrait interview of Graham by former Portrait Gallery director Marc Pachter. Amy Henderson is the curator for this exhibition.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: 'Hide/Seek' considers such themes as the role of sexual difference in depicting modern America; how artists explored the fluidity of sexuality and gender; how major themes in modern art - especially abstraction - were influenced by social marginalization; and how art reflected society's evolving and changing attitudes toward sexuality, desire, and romantic attachment.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Impressionism and the Gilded Age at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: The museum has one of the finest and largest collections from the last quarter of the nineteenth century, including impressionist and Gilded Age works.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Glimpse of the Past: A Neighborhood Evolves at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: 'Glimpse of the Past' is a photographic exploration of the neighborhood surrounding the Patent Office Building, one of the oldest federal buildings in Washington, D.C. and now home to the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum. On display are images from the 1850s to the present, which showcase the rise, decline and revival of the area. An interactive in the exhibition will also feature snapshots of the area during the 1960s and 1970s made by Washingtonian Chris Earnshaw.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Sloth Bear Feeding at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Find out what and how these Asian bears eat.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: John Gossage: the Pond at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: The installation of 'John Gossage: The Pond' celebrates the recent gift to the museum of this remarkable photographic series and the re-issue of one of the most influential photography books of the past three decades.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Meet A Great Ape Keeper at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Learn about the fascinating world of apes. A keeper will speak about gorillas or orangutans.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Alexis Rockman: A Fable for Tomorrow at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: 'Alexis Rockman: A Fable for Tomorrow' is the first major survey of the artist's work and features nearly fifty paintings and works on paper from private and public collections. The exhibition traces Rockman's artistic development from the mid-1980s to the present.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Orangutan Crossing at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: See the orangutans traveling on the Zoo's Orangutan Transport System, or O Line. The best time to see them is between 11 am and 11:30 am (weather dependent).

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Holiday Festival of Trains at Ellicott City Station at B & O Railroad Museum's Ellicott City Station
properties.description: This annual holiday celebration of toy trains and model railroading features a new multi-dimensional O-gauge model train layout, a Thomas the Tank engine layout and the Museum's permanent HO model train layout inside the Freight House. Meet Santa and Frosty the Snowman on certain weekends throughout the festival.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Cultural Center Exhibition: V Inter-American Biennial of Video Art at Inter-American Development Bank Cultural Center
properties.description: 20 videos from 11 countries, including Puerto Rico, comprise the 5th edition of the IDB Cultural Center Video Biennial. Winning and selected videos, from an international call to Latin American and Caribbean artists for 5-minute videos, creatively explore and broaden the discussion of factors that affect the social, cultural and economic environments in the Region. Exhibition includes First, Second and Third Prize winners, Honorable Mentions, and additional entries selected from among 223 sent by artists from 20 countries.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Leslie Nolan - Off-Kilter at Touchstone Gallery
properties.description: This exhibit features color drenched figurative paintings by Leslie Nolan.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Yaw Obuobi: Rhythmic Pulse at International Visions
properties.description: On display in the gallery are yarn collages by Ghanaian artist Yaw Obuobi.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Guided Tours of the Baltimore Basilica at Baltimore Basilica
properties.description: This tour includes all areas of the church, including the upper church, undercroft, Our Lady Seat of Wisdom Chapel, Crypt, Basilica Museum, and the Pope John Paul II Prayer Garden (upon request). Tours last approximately 45 minutes to one hour. If you would like to incorporate the Pope John Paul II Prayer Garden into your tour, add another 15 minutes.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Great Ape Research Demonstration at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Meet a cognitive researcher and learn about studies being conducted with the Zoo's orangutans and gorillas.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Bird Enrichment Demonstration at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Watch birds forage and catch their food mid-flight, as a keeper or volunteer narrates in the Indoor Flight Room.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: No Edition: Paintly Prints by Lou Stovall at Addison Ripley Fine Art
Jan 13, 2011: Gene Davis: Drawings at Marsha Mateyka Gallery
Jan 13, 2011: Anish Kapoor: Prints at Marsha Mateyka Gallery
Jan 13, 2011: Jim Sanborn: Photographs at Marsha Mateyka Gallery
Jan 13, 2011: Amazon Fish Feeding at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Thousands of fish species live in the Amazon River Basin. Meet some of them during this feeding in Amazonia.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Nihal Kececi: Memories Matter at Touchstone Gallery
properties.description: This exhibit features a series of impressionistic paintings.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Octopus Feeding at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Learn more about the giant Pacific octopus, a predator that demonstrates dynamic hunting behaviors.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Tim Pawlenty: Courage to Stand at Fourth Estate Restaurant at National Press Club
properties.description: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota and a potential Republican presidential candidate in 2012, will speak at a National Press Club luncheon. Pawlenty, who will leave the governor's office Jan. 3, will launch his book tour at the National Press Club for his memoir 'Courage to Stand.' In his book, Pawlenty tells his story of going from blue-collar South St. Paul to the governor's mansion, about his time as governor and shares his ideas for the direction of the country and how some of the things he's done in Minnesota might translate nationally. Pawlenty will sign copies of his book from 2 pm- 2:30 pm, after the luncheon. The National Press Club luncheon will begin promptly at 12:30 pm and Pawlenty's remarks will begin just after 1 pm, followed by a question-and-answer session.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: STOMP at Martin Luther King Jr Memorial Library
properties.description: Performers from STOMP will "play the library" - making noise in an unexpected place. Feel free to stop by with your lunch and enjoy the show.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: An Old Brick House in Georgian Style: 190 Years of History in the Beall-Dawson House at Beall-Dawson House
properties.description: This year-long retrospective of the Beall-Dawson House, built circa 1815, examines the architecture, landscape and history of the property from the perspective of the many individuals - free and enslaved - who lived, played, worked and died here.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Ben Gest at Contemporary Museum
properties.description: 'Ben Gest: Commissure' is Part 3 of Project 20, a two-year celebration of the Contemporary Museum's 20th anniversary with exhibitions and projects curated by former Contemporary Museum directors, curators and exhibiting artists. Photographer Ben Gest creates complex and psychologically-charged portraits constructed from dozens and at times hundreds of digital photographs.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Inked Souls 3 at Art Whino
properties.description: Art Whino joins forces with Tagur Footwear once again for their third edition of 'Inked Souls,' an exhibition featuring customized sneakers and fine art by local, national and international leaders in the pop surrealism/urban contemporary art movement.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Levi Stephens at Old Post Office Pavilion
properties.description: Levi Stephens plays alternative soul.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Living Legends of Alexandria at Northern Virginia Community College,
properties.description: The Photography Program at the Alexandria Campus of Northern Virginia Community College (NOVA) will host this exhibit in the Tyler Gallery. The public is also invited to a reception on Jan. 13 from 5:30 pm-7 -pm and to a gallery presentation on Jan. 20 at 6 pm.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Small Mammal Feeding at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: At this feeding demonstration, you'll learn more about what small mammals like to eat.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Guided Tours of the Anderson House Museum at Anderson House Museum
properties.description: This museum houses artifacts from the Revolutionary War, portraits by early American artists, 18th-century paintings, 17th-century tapestries, decorative arts of Europe and Asia and displays of books, medals, swords, silver, glass, china and more.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Guided Tours of the Baltimore Basilica at Baltimore Basilica
properties.description: This tour includes all areas of the church, including the upper church, undercroft, Our Lady Seat of Wisdom Chapel, Crypt, Basilica Museum, and the Pope John Paul II Prayer Garden (upon request). Tours last approximately 45 minutes to one hour. If you would like to incorporate the Pope John Paul II Prayer Garden into your tour, add another 15 minutes.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Guided Tours of the Anderson House Museum at Anderson House Museum
properties.description: This museum houses artifacts from the Revolutionary War, portraits by early American artists, 18th-century paintings, 17th-century tapestries, decorative arts of Europe and Asia and displays of books, medals, swords, silver, glass, china and more.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Meet A Small Mammal at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: An animal keeper will introduce you to one of the Zoo's small mammals like an armadillo or naked mole-rat.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Spider Feeding at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Get up close and personal with the golden orb weaver spiders.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Lunchtime With Piranhas at National Aquarium
properties.description: Watch as the piranhas hunt for their meal and learn more about their interlocking teeth and feeding behaviors.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Annie at Olney Theater Center for the Arts
properties.description: This heart-warming musical is based upon the popular Harold Gray comic strip - Little Orphan Annie.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Nonprofits Profit at Madam's Organ
properties.description: The Thursday's Nonprofits Profit at Madam's Organ fundraiser program began in 2005 as a way for Madam's Organ to help local nonprofits raise money and awareness for their causes. Featured nonprofits receive $1 from every drink sold and 20 percent of the food sales between 5 pm-9 pm. Nonprofits are also allowed to hold silent auctions or drawings, sell merchandise, and take donations on site to maximize the fundraising opportunity.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Crustacean Feeding at The Smithsonian National Zoological Park
properties.description: Zoo visitors will have the opportunity to see the crabs, lobsters, shrimp and crayfish get their dinner.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Guided Tours of the Anderson House Museum at Anderson House Museum
properties.description: This museum houses artifacts from the Revolutionary War, portraits by early American artists, 18th-century paintings, 17th-century tapestries, decorative arts of Europe and Asia and displays of books, medals, swords, silver, glass, china and more.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Nonprofits Profit at Madam's Organ
properties.description: The Thursday's Nonprofits Profit at Madam's Organ fundraiser program began in 2005 as a way for Madam's Organ to help local nonprofits raise money and awareness for their causes. Featured nonprofits receive $1 from every drink sold and 20 percent of the food sales between 5 pm-9 pm. Nonprofits are also allowed to hold silent auctions or drawings, sell merchandise, and take donations on site to maximize the fundraising opportunity.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Railsplitter at Velvet Lounge
Jan 13, 2011: Sanford Markley at Murphy's Grand Irish Pub
properties.description: Sanford Markley's deft guitar work creates a third voice - percussive and vibrant. His unique style displays cascading counter melodies, warm tones which rise, fall, swell and surge between the notes and chords of the vocals. The result is a fullness of sound that deceives the listener into believing that there is more here than simply an acoustic guitar and a beautiful voice.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: LIVE Interactive Painting With Artist Brian Kirhagis at Au Pied
properties.description: Age restriction: 21 and over. This is a LIVE Interactive Painting with Artist Brian Kirhagis. Guests are invited to participate and put brush to canvas. This is a very unique event because the artist will bring a new painting alive starting on a blank canvass with guest participation. Go to this link to see a previous event at Velour- http://vimeo.com/15148169

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Bert Kreischer - From Comedy Central, "Last Comic Standing 2" & Travel Channels "Bert The Conqueror" at DC Impov Comedy Club & Restaurant
properties.description:
Bert Kreischer grew up in Tampa, Florida. While attending Florida State University, he was discovered by Rolling Stone Magazine and given the title 'The #1 Party Animal in the Country' in a six-page article entitled 'The Undergraduate.' This article set his comedy career in motion. Oliver Stone optioned the rights to his life, book deals were offered, and he moved to New York City to pursue Stand-up Comedy. He began working at the Boston Comedy Club, within a year Will Smith signed him to a television development deal, he moved to LA, and shortly there after was co-hosting 'The X-show' on FX. A few months later he signed his second television development deal with CBS, where he made his acting debut starring in the CBS/20th Century Fox pilot, 'Life with David J' with Elliot Gould. 
Bert has appeared on Comedy Central's 'Premium Blend', 'Shorties Watchin Shorties', VH-1, FX's 'Hurt Bert', 'The Shield', 'Last Comic Standing 2', 'Jimmy Kimmel Live', and currently hosts Spike TV's 'Fresh Baked Video Games' which airs every Saturday night at midnight. 
Bert also tours clubs and colleges all over the country and performs regularly at the Hollywood Improv.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: A Shadow of Honor at Church Street Theater
properties.description: Keegan Theatre presents the world premiere of Peter Coy's 'A Shadow of Honor,' where past and present collide as a new generation faces the repercussions of war - and something has to give.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Tuck & Patti at Blues Alley
properties.description: For 30 years, husband-and-wife duo Tuck Andress and Patti Cathcart have mesmerized audiences with their unique blend of jazz and pop music. Their recent effort, 'I Remember You' features some of Tuck and Patti's favorites from the Great American Songbook, including renditions of classics by Duke Ellington, George Gershwin, Rodgers & Hart, Jerome Kern and more.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Kareem Green at Comedy Factory
properties.description: Green has been seen on BET's 'Comic View' and NBC's 'Showtime at the Apollo.'

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Bert Kreischer - From Comedy Central, "Last Comic Standing 2" & Travel Channels "Bert The Conqueror" at DC Impov Comedy Club & Restaurant
properties.description:
Bert Kreischer grew up in Tampa, Florida. While attending Florida State University, he was discovered by Rolling Stone Magazine and given the title 'The #1 Party Animal in the Country' in a six-page article entitled 'The Undergraduate.' This article set his comedy career in motion. Oliver Stone optioned the rights to his life, book deals were offered, and he moved to New York City to pursue Stand-up Comedy. He began working at the Boston Comedy Club, within a year Will Smith signed him to a television development deal, he moved to LA, and shortly there after was co-hosting 'The X-show' on FX. A few months later he signed his second television development deal with CBS, where he made his acting debut starring in the CBS/20th Century Fox pilot, 'Life with David J' with Elliot Gould. 
Bert has appeared on Comedy Central's 'Premium Blend', 'Shorties Watchin Shorties', VH-1, FX's 'Hurt Bert', 'The Shield', 'Last Comic Standing 2', 'Jimmy Kimmel Live', and currently hosts Spike TV's 'Fresh Baked Video Games' which airs every Saturday night at midnight. 
Bert also tours clubs and colleges all over the country and performs regularly at the Hollywood Improv.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: International Guitar Night at The Barns at Wolf Trap
properties.description:
The world’s premier touring guitar festival; innovative masters of the acoustic guitar get together for a special evening to exchange styles and solos.
    * England-native Clive Carroll started playing the banjo at age 2, has released 3 solo albums, and was described by Acoustic Guitar as “probably the best and most original young acoustic guitar player and composer in Britain.”
    * Son of Brazilian composer/guitarist Egberto Gismonti, Alexandre Gismonti has developed his own distinct musical language, representing his country at music festivals around the world.
    * Pino Forastiere of Italy received his degree in classical guitar at the Santa Cecilia Conservatory in Rome in 1992. In March 2010 he premiered with Guitar Republic, a new acoustic guitar trio in which he performs with Sergio Altamura and Stefano Barone.
    * Known as a “poet of the guitar,” American Brian Gore is the founder of International Guitar Night and published the book Fingerstyle Guitar: Lessons in Technique and Creativity in 2005.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Big Bad Voodoo Daddy at Ram's Head
properties.description: Be prepared to hit the dance floor when the hot swing ensemble Big Bad Voodoo Daddy comes to town. This band was featured in the hit movie 'Swingers.' Although their songs sound like they were lifted right out of the Zoot-suited '40s, the band writes all its own material, taking swing into a raw and modern direction.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Jammin’ Java’s Mid-Atlantic Band Battle IIII at Jammin' Java
properties.description: Jammin Java presents The FOURTH Mid-Atlantic Band Battle. Everyone had such a killer time at the 1st, 2nd and 3rd Battle that we’re doing it all over again! We are searching for the best bands of any genre from up-and-down the East Coast to prove that they have what it takes to win $2500 CASH, your own headlining show at Jammin Java, Studio time @ Cue Recording Studios w/ producer Jim Ebert and Gift Certificates from Chuck Levin’s Washington Music Center for the top 4 bands. Here's how it works: 1. Apply to compete in the Battle. Only 24 bands will be accepted. 2. Compete in one of four preliminary rounds on January 10, 11, 12 and 13. Six bands compete per night. One winner per night moves on to the finals. 3. Four bands compete in the finals on Friday, February 18th. 4. Win the Battle and you get $2500 CASH, your own headlining show at Jammin Java, Studio time @ Cue Recording Studios w/ producer Jim Ebert and Gift Certificates from Chuck Levin’s Washington Music Center for the top 4 bands. This is a great opportunity for some MAJOR CASH for your band (buy a van, new gear, add to your recording fund?) as well as tons of exposure to many industry professionals. It's also a great way for us at Jammin Java to check out your band in consideration for future shows. ALL GENRES ARE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY TO THE BATTLE! Whether you are acoustic, rock, latin, bluegrass, funk, folk, electronic, reggae, hip-hop, or anything else, we want you! TO APPLY: go to myspace.com/jjbandbattle and fill out the form OR email jjbandbattle@gmail.com with the following info: Band Name: Contact Person: Email: Phone: Myspace URL: Location: The application deadline is Saturday, November 20th.http://www.myspace.com/jjbandbattle

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: International Guitar Night at The Barns at Wolf Trap
properties.description: 'International Guitar Night' was founded by San Francisco steel-string fingerstyle player Brian Gore, who has been praised for his masterful playing and distinctive blend of fingerstyle and percussive techniques. Each year, Gore assembles a cross-section of the world's acoustic virtuosos for a touring guitar festival.

Jan 13, 2011: American Spiritual Ensemble at Asbury United Methodist Church
properties.description: The ensemble's repertoire ranges from spirituals to Broadway, highlighting the African-American experience through song and dance.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Washington Stage Guild: Magic at The Undercroft Theater of Mount Vernon Place United Methodist Church
properties.description: The Washington Stage Guild welcomes 2011 with a witty fairy-tale of a comedy, 'Magic' by G.K. Chesterton.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: The 40 Dollar Fine Band at Bangkok Blues
properties.description: The 40 Dollar Fine Band plays roots music from Maryland.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Introduction to the Winter Night Sky at Audubon Naturalist Society
properties.description: Can you spot Orion the hunter rising up just over the treetops? This alone is a sure sign that winter has come once again to the northern hemisphere. Being able to read the sky in winter can give you a unique sense of cosmological wonder since most of the brighter stars are, in fact, winter stars. While our leader is best-known for his expertise in dragonflies, he'll share his equally strong knowledge of astronomy in an indoor/outdoor presentation at our Woodend Sanctuary. We'll be introduced to sky guideposts and the dozen or so "winter" constellations, before bundling up to head outside to look for some of these wondrous celestial sights through a telescope.

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Jeffrey Osborne at Birchmere
properties.description: Jeffrey Osborne is best known for his 1982 single, 'On the Wings of Love.'

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Jeffrey Osborne at Birchmere
properties.description: Jeffrey Osborne is best known for his 1982 single, 'On the Wings of Love.'

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: MAGFest 9 at Hilton Mark Center
properties.description: MAGFest is a video and computer gaming festival run by fans, for fans. It's similar to an anime or scifi convention, but aims to be more of a laid-back video game party. Nearly everything is open 24-hours. The show floors aren't crowded but still filled with lots of fan art, film and music. Our special guests fit right in and socialize with everyone. Game movies and cartoons are shown all weekend. In addition to our 10,000 square foot game room, lots of attendees set up games in their rooms and invite others inside. Perhaps most importantly, MAGFest has a huge focus on game music -- multiple concerts' worth -- filled with video game music tributes, some even with the original composers! On Thursday, Friday, and Saturday nights, multiple bands will perform on our main stage, and our JamSpace room is open 24 hours for collaborative music and special treats alike. Want to pre-register? http://magfest.org/prereg Want to staff? http://magfest.org/volunteer Reserve a room: http://magfest.org/getaroom Want to use a phone thingy? Call +1 (507) 2-GAMING (that's +1 507 242-6464) and leave us a message!

properties.title: Jan 13, 2011: Mo Co Public Forum on Drugs and Alcohol at Executive Office Building (Mont Co. EOB), Auditorium
properties.description:
Substance Abuse and Addiction In Montgomery County:
How Are We Doing?
Thursday, January 13, 2011
7 PM – 9 PM
Executive Office Building (EOB)
101 Monroe St, Auditorium
Rockville, MD 20850
Honoree and Keynote Speaker:
Councilmember Duchy Trachtenberg
AODAAC Annual Public Forum  (The Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse Advisory Council of Montgomery County)
AODAAC is the citizen advisory board to the Montgomery County Government regarding alcohol and other drugs to provide guidance to government leaders about public policy and service programs.
The Council holds an annual forum to hear the public’s suggestions, concerns, criticisms and kudos of the county government’s efforts in this area. Time will be reserved for unscheduled speakers to voice their thoughts. The event may be videotaped by County Cable 6 for future airing on the channel. Speakers may include:
• citizens in recovery from addiction,
• families confronting substance abuse problems,
• charities and other non-profit organizations struggling with community needs,
• parents, educational organizations, or student groups,
• other concerned citizens.
Free and open to the public.

Jan 13, 2011: Adobe-Photoshop Advanced: Web and Video at Future Media Concepts
properties.description: http://www.fmctraining.com/fmc.asp?l=Washington+DC&p2=Upcoming+Classes Contact:202-429-9700 / MartinD@FMCtraining.com (2 day class) (2011)1/13-14, 2/22-23, 4/21-22, 6/27-28, 8/18-19 This 2-day course provides a thorough overview for experienced users who wish to further their effectiveness on Photoshop. This class is aimed at the Photoshop professional who needs to enhance their knowledge to work with web and video images more effectively. The course is an ideal combination of instructor-led demonstration and hands-on practice. Prerequisites: Photoshop Fundamentals: An Introduction to Photoshop class or equivalent experience. Course Outline: Lesson 1: How Digital Images work * Understanding image size and resolution * Understanding DPI and PPI * Understanding additive and subtractive colors * Understanding bit depth * The additive color model * Web-safe colors * Hexadecimal color codes * Web and video resolution * Video safe colors * Pixel aspect ratio and how it can affect your image Lesson 2: Vector Graphics * Understanding Vector Images * The Pen Tool * Vector Shapes and Masks * Using Vector Images in Video Editing applications (FCP, Premiere Pro) Lesson 3: Preparing Files for the Web * Selecting a web design workspace * Exporting HTML and images * Using the Zoomify feature * Creating a web gallery * PNGs, JPGs & GIFs- the right file type for the right job * Designing in Photoshop for Flash Lesson 4: Slices * Laying out a web page in Photoshop * Layer-based slices * Hyperlinks & rollovers (rollovers explained partly in Fireworks, Dreamweaver or Flash) Lesson 5: Video and Animation * Adding animation * Animating a layer style * The video timeline * Importing & exporting video files * Rotoscoping * Retouching video * Exporting Photoshop layers to your nonlinear editor * Using Photoshop with a video monitor Lesson 6: Vanishing Point * Setting up a Vanishing Point grid * Adding Planes to the Grid * Adjusting the angle of the grid * Export for After Effects (VPE) Lesson 7: Actions * Understanding Actions * Using Actions * Creating Actions * Batch Processing * Using Actions to create web galleries & PDF presentations Lesson 8: Designing graphics for video * Aspect ratio- square vs. nonsquare pixels * Previewing video images in Photoshop * Broadcast legal colors (Vectorscope and Waveform Monitor) * Understanding interlaced / Progressive frames * Action safe & title safe guides * Creating DVD menus in Photoshop (for Encore) Lesson 9: Device central * Designing for PDAs/smart phones * Previewing your image * Changing your device Lesson 10: Introduction to 3D Images * Getting Started * Creating a 3D shape from a layer * Manipulating 3D objects * Using the 3D panel to adjust lighting and surface texture * Merging two-dimensional layers onto 3D layers * Importing 3D files * Merging 3D layers to share the same 3D space * Adding a spot light * Painting on a 3D object * Using Repoussé to create 3D text * Creating a 3D postcard

properties.description:
From cartoon musical inspired improv to hilarity through the radio age to the iPod age WIT will keep you laughing and entertained at this year’s Capital Fringe Festival
Join Audio Files and iToonsical at Source Theater on Saturday and Sunday 7.8-7.23 at 8PM and 10PM and Sunday 7.10-7.24 at 2PM, 8PM and 10PM for giggles, chuckles, snickers and straight up rolling-on-the-floor laughter.
iToonsical takes on Disney’s most prized possession with completely improvised scenes, lyrics and music all inspired by audience suggestion. Then comes a two-in-one deal with Audio Files, a combination of WIT’s show’s The Source and WIRT. First, WIRT uses only their voices to adventure back to the time of detective radio shows. Then The Source shifts to modern times, hijacking an audience member’s iPod to create a score to their improvised scene.
Tickets for Audio Files, iToonsical and the many other Fringe shows will go on sale June 20th. For more information about Capital Fringe, check out their website at capitalfringe.org or head over to Fort Fringe & the Baldacchino Gypsy Tent Bar at 607 New York Ave. NW.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: John Witherspoon from "The Boondocks," "House Party" and the "Friday" trilogy at DC Improv Comedy Club
properties.description:
You probably remember John Witherspoon as Ice Cube's outrageously funny, dog-catching father in the "Friday" movie trilogy, where the two were the only cast members to appear in all three movies, including "Next Friday" & "Friday After Next." You may also remember him as Pops on the long-running sitcom "The Wayans Brothers," or as Spoon on The Tracy Morgan Show on NBC. You might have also heard him as the voice of Robert "Granddad" Freeman on the hit animated series "The Boondocks." No matter how familiar you are with John, once you see him perform live you completely understand why he's has earned his reputation as one of the funniest dads in America.
John's scene-stealing roles in "Boomerang," "Little Nicky," "House Party," "Vampire in Brooklyn," and "I'm Gonna Git You Sucka," has established him as a Hollywood mainstay. Witherspoon's resume spans over four decades and his performances in blockbuster movies, hit-television shows, and top-rated music videos have left an impression on legions of fans who instantly recognize his signature catchphrases like "Bang!Bang!Bang!Bang!" "You gotta co-ordinate!" and "Don't nobody go in the bathroom..."
According to the Orange County Register, John's expressive talent puts him in a class of his own. "Witherspoon is one of those performers who doesn't need a funny line to be funny. Just standing there in a truculent posture with a suspicious look, he is funny and enlivens every scene he's in." The Detroit-bred comic has proven that he is a Hollywood mainstay and continues to land coveted spots in some of America's favorite movies and television shows. Witherspoon continues to tour around the country with his wildly popular stand-up show, plus he's recently launched The John Witherspoon Collection, a complete line of humorous greeting cards called Spoon Cards.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Capital Portraits: Treasures From Washington Private Collections at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: This exhibition presents portraits that reside in private Washington, D.C. collections. Many of the works have never been on public display. Works included are by major artists such as John Singleton Copley, Mary Cassatt, Andy Warhol and Kehinde Wiley. Featuring aesthetically superior images from 1750 to the present, this exhibition demonstrates how portraiture is ingrained in the private sphere of people's lives and offers an insiders peek to the public.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: 150th Commemoration of the Civil War: the Death of Ellsworth at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: This exhibition recounts the death of Colonel Elmer E. Ellsworth in Alexandria, VA. Ellsworth, a friend of President Abraham Lincoln, was the first Union officer to be killed in the four-year-long struggle. Throughout the Civil War his name, face and heroism was recalled in stationery, sheet music and memorial lithographs. Francis E. Brownell, the soldier who mortally avenged Ellsworth's assailant, bequeathed several artifacts to the Smithsonian Institution, including the weapons used in the incident and Brownell's Congressional Medal of Honor. The exhibition will bring together a select grouping of once-prized mementoes, including portraits of Ellsworth and Lincoln, as well as Alonzo Chappel's historic painting, 'The Death of Ellsworth.'

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: To Make A World: George Ault and 1940s America at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: This exhibition centers on five paintings Ault made between 1943 and 1948 depicting the crossroads of Russell's Corners in Woodstock, N.Y. The additional 22 artists represented in this exhibition include some as celebrated as Edward Hopper and Andrew Wyeth, while others are scarcely known to today's art audiences. Taken together, their artworks reveal an aesthetic vein running through 1940s American art that previously has not been identified. From their remote corners of the country, these artists conveyed a still quietude that seems filled with potentialities.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Close to Home: Photographers and Their Families at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: 'Close to Home' presents photographs made during the past three decades by both established and emerging artists. On display are 32 color and black-and-white photographs from the Smithsonian American Art Museum's permanent collection by nine contemporary photographers: Tina Barney, Virginia Beahan, Christopher Dawson, Muriel Hasbun, Martina Lopez, Elaine O'Neil, Larry Sultan, Margaret Strickland, and Carrie Will. The exhibition includes many new acquisitions, which will be on view at the museum for the first time. Toby Jurovics, formerly the museum's curator of photography, selected the photographs in the installation.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Calder's Portraits: A New Language at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: Best known for his abstract mobiles and stabiles, Alexander Calder (1898-1976) was also a prolific portraitist. This unprecedented exhibition will feature Calder's work alongside contemporary documents - photographs, drawings, and especially caricatures by such artist-illustrators as Paolo Garretto, Miguel Covarrubias, and Paul Colin - and will pose questions regarding the line between fine-art portraiture and caricature.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Glimpse of the Past: A Neighborhood Evolves at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: 'Glimpse of the Past' is a photographic exploration of the neighborhood surrounding the Patent Office Building, one of the oldest federal buildings in Washington, D.C. and now home to the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum. On display are images from the 1850s to the present, which showcase the rise, decline and revival of the area. An interactive in the exhibition will also feature snapshots of the area during the 1960s and 1970s made by Washingtonian Chris Earnshaw.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: From Impressionism to Modernism: the Chester Dale Collection at National Gallery of Art - East Building
properties.description: This exhibit will bring together 84 of the finest French and American paintings that Chester Dale and his wife Maud, an artist and critic, assembled from the 1920s through the 1950s.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Seasons: Chinese Flowers at Freer Gallery of Art
properties.description: This exhibition features paintings of Chinese flowers native to each season.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Archival Summer Seminar in Germany 2011 at German Historical Institute
properties.description: The program trains participants to read old German script, familiarizes them with German research facilities (archives and libraries), provides a forum for discussing research methods, and helps prepare them for their prospective dissertation research trips to Germany.
